Expectation1: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation1: A file for a straightforward procedural hearing scheduled in two weeks has just been delivered to your chambers for preliminary review.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A surprise, tie-breaking vote on a critical piece of legislation is happening in the next hour, and you must immediately contact the undecided representative.
Story: I sat at my desk, the thick manila folder for the upcoming hearing staring back at me. As a judge, I’m expected to review every detail, no matter how routine the case may seem. The hearing was in two weeks, but I prided myself on being thorough and prepared well in advance. Just as I reached for the file, my phone buzzed with an urgent message from my activist group: the legislature was holding a surprise vote on a bill I’d spent months fighting for. The outcome would hinge on a single, undecided representative, and I was the one with the connection to sway them. My heart pounded. I could already hear the voices of my colleagues, reminding me of the importance of impartiality and diligence. Yet, the activist in me screamed that this was the moment to make a difference. I stared at the file, then at my phone, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my undivided loyalty.
